title: Old-Time Expressions
description: Do you remember what these vintage expressions mean? Test your knowledge of old-fashioned slang, idioms, and phrases that were once part of everyday speech!

questions.question: What does the old expression "the bee's knees" mean?
options: An outstanding or excellent person or thing
questions.explanation: "The bee's knees" became popular in the 1920s flapper era and means something or someone outstanding or excellent. It was part of a trend of nonsense phrases like "the cat's pajamas" and "the cat's meow" that all meant the same thing — the height of excellence.

questions.question: If someone told you "don't take any wooden nickels," what were they saying?
options: Don't be foolish or get cheated
questions.explanation: "Don't take any wooden nickels" dates back to the early 1900s and was a lighthearted way of saying "be careful" or "don't let anyone swindle you." It was commonly used as a parting phrase, similar to "take care of yourself."

questions.question: What did it mean to call someone a "wet blanket"?
options: A person who dampens others' enthusiasm or fun
questions.explanation: A "wet blanket" is a person who spoils other people's fun or enthusiasm. The expression dates to the early 1800s and comes from the practice of using a wet blanket to smother a fire — just as the person smothers the enjoyment of others.

questions.question: What does "23 skidoo" mean?
options: A card game popular in saloons
To leave quickly or get out
questions.explanation: "23 skidoo" was one of the first widespread slang expressions in America, popular from around 1906. It means to leave quickly, scram, or get going. Its exact origin is debated, but it was so popular that it became a catchphrase of the early 20th century.

questions.question: If something was described as "the cat's pajamas," what did that mean?
questions.explanation: "The cat's pajamas" originated in the 1920s and means something excellent or superlative. Coined during the Jazz Age, it was part of a fad of combining animal names with human clothing or body parts to describe something outstanding, alongside "the bee's knees" and "the cat's meow."

questions.question: What did it mean when someone said "he really knows his onions"?
options: He is very knowledgeable about a subject
questions.explanation: "Knows his onions" was 1920s slang meaning someone is very knowledgeable or well-informed about a particular subject. Some etymologists believe it may reference S.G. Onions, a British lexicographer, though this is debated. Similar expressions included "knows his stuff" and "knows his beans."

questions.question: What was meant by the expression "burning the midnight oil"?
options: Working or studying late into the night
questions.explanation: "Burning the midnight oil" means staying up late to work or study. The expression dates back to the 1600s, when people literally burned oil in lamps to see after dark. It was widely used through the 20th century and remains in use today.

questions.question: If someone was called a "drugstore cowboy," what did that mean?
options: A pharmacist in a western town
A man who loitered in public places to flirt with women
A rodeo performer who got injured often
questions.explanation: A "drugstore cowboy" was 1920s–1930s slang for a man who hung around drugstores, street corners, or other public places trying to pick up women, rather than doing honest work. The term implied someone who dressed sharply but was all style and no substance.

questions.question: What did it mean to "get the sack"?
options: To be fired from a job
questions.explanation: "Getting the sack" means being dismissed from employment. The expression may date back to the days when tradesmen carried their own tools in a sack — when an employer handed you your sack, it meant your services were no longer needed. It was common parlance throughout the 20th century.

questions.question: What was a "fuddy-duddy"?
options: An old-fashioned, fussy, or stuffy person
questions.explanation: A "fuddy-duddy" is a person who is old-fashioned, overly conservative, or fussy. The term appeared in the early 1900s and was widely used by the mid-20th century. Its exact origin is uncertain, but it may come from the Scottish word "duddy" meaning ragged or shabby.

questions.question: What did the expression "sold down the river" originally mean?
options: To be tricked in a business deal
To move to a town downstream
To be betrayed, originating from the sale of enslaved people to harsher plantations in the Deep South
To buy cheap goods from a riverboat merchant
questions.explanation: "Sold down the river" has a painful origin: it referred to enslaved people in the Upper South being sold to plantations further down the Mississippi River, where conditions were often far more brutal. By the mid-20th century, it came to broadly mean being betrayed or cheated by someone you trusted.

questions.question: If someone was described as being "on the lam," what were they doing?
questions.explanation: "On the lam" means running away or fleeing, especially from law enforcement. The expression became popular in the late 1800s and early 1900s. "Lam" likely comes from the Scandinavian word "lamja," meaning to beat or thrash — the idea being to "beat it" or run away quickly.

questions.question: What did it mean to call someone a "gadabout"?
options: A person who travels from place to place for pleasure
questions.explanation: A "gadabout" is a person who goes from place to place in search of amusement or social activity. The word dates to the early 1800s, combining "gad" (to roam or wander) with "about." It was commonly used through the mid-20th century, often with a mildly disapproving tone.

questions.question: What did the expression "fly off the handle" mean?
questions.explanation: "Fly off the handle" means to suddenly lose one's temper. The expression dates to the 1800s American frontier and comes from the real danger of axe heads flying off their handles during chopping — a sudden, uncontrolled, and potentially dangerous event, much like an outburst of anger.

questions.question: What did it mean to be "in cahoots" with someone?
options: To be secretly plotting or conspiring together
To be living in the same house
To be competing against each other
questions.explanation: "In cahoots" means to be conspiring or working together secretly, often for dishonest purposes. The word "cahoot" appeared in American English in the early 1800s, possibly derived from the French "cahute" meaning a small hut or cabin — suggesting people huddled together in secret.
